title: Multi-Digit Multiplication

vocab.definition: The result of multiplying one part of a number by another number
To trade 10 ones for 1 ten, 10 tens for 1 hundred, etc.
The traditional method for solving multiplication problems step by step
A visual way to show multiplication using rectangles

teachingNotes: Introduce area models before standard algorithm. Use base-10 blocks and grid paper. Connect to real-world contexts like finding areas.

sample.question: Use the area model to find 23 × 15.
Explain how partial products work for 34 × 12.
Why does 0 in the ones place add a zero in the next line of the algorithm?

truefalse.question: When multiplying 34 × 26, you can break it down using the distributive property.
In the standard algorithm, you always add the partial products.
An area model for 12 × 25 uses three rectangles.
expectedAny: two by two parts → four rectangles

truefalse.question: Regrouping is never used in multiplication.
Partial products must be in a specific order to be correct.

multiplechoice.question: What is the first step in solving 47 × 38 using partial products?
Which is a correct partial product of 63 × 24?
Which model shows the distributive property?
In 406 × 3, which digit is multiplied by 3 to get 18 tens?

fillintheblank.question: To find 24 × 13, I can multiply 20 × 13 = _____ and 4 × 13 = _____, then add them.
When multiplying 203 × 4, the hundreds contribution is _____.
An area model for 15 × 19 has rectangles with areas 10×10, 10×9, 5×10, and 5×9. The largest is _____.

shortanswer.question: Explain why the area model helps with multiplication.
expectedAny: breaks large problems into smaller parts

shortanswer.question: Describe how regrouping appears in the standard algorithm for 48 × 7.
How does place value explain the zero in the second line of 34 × 20?
Give two different ways to compute 25 × 16.
Why is estimating useful before multiplying large numbers?
What properties of multiplication are shown by partial products?
When would you prefer an area model over the standard algorithm?

wordProblems.question: A school auditorium has 28 rows with 24 seats in each row. How many seats are there in total?
A bakery makes 36 trays of cookies, with 18 cookies on each tray. How many cookies are made?
There are 25 teams in a league and each team plays 14 games. How many games total are played (counting each game once)?
expectedAny: Assume schedule total per team is 14; total team-games is 350

wordProblems.question: A rectangle measures 27 cm by 19 cm. What is its area?
A store orders 42 boxes of pencils with 12 pencils per box. How many pencils?
There are 16 classrooms with 28 desks each. How many desks in all?
A farmer plants 34 rows of corn with 25 plants in each row. How many plants?
